@graph.description: This is a test datacrate of files pulled automatically from the HIEv application

@graph.creator: John Drake (je.drake@uws.edu.au)
@graph.description:
Data relevant to heatwave damage from the canopy harvest for the fourth whole-tree chamber experiment (WTC4) with Eucalyptus parramattensis. Note that other data were collected during the canopy harvest that are not summarized in this file.

Variables:
chamber: "C01", "C02", etc
layer: canopies were divided into three layers of equal heights (i.e., thirds). "LOW', "MID", and "TOP".
Leaf_DW: the total leaf dry weight observed in each layer (g)
SLA: the specific leaf area of a 100-leaf subsample. (cm2/g).
HW_damage_DW: the total dry weight of leaves that had visible heat damage (g)

@graph.creator: John Drake (je.drake@uws.edu.au)
@graph.description:
Fortnightly (two-weekly) biometry measurements from the fourth whole tree chamber experiment (WTC4) with Eucalyptus parramattensis. Every second Wednesday, Burhan and company (often Angelica and Tamara), measured the stem dimensions of all 12 trees.

At the very beginning of the experiment, there were multiple potted plants in each chamber, so there were multiple pots per chamber. After the trees were planted in the ground, diameter was measured 15-cm-height, 30-cm-height, and then at ~30-cm increments up the stem of each tree. The 15-cm and 30-cm measurements were abandoned after the plastic floors were installed. The diameter measurement at 65-cm-height may be particularly useful, as it is close to "basal diameter" and it was measured throughout the entire experiment. A few trees forked late in the experiment, and thus have multiple stems.

Variables:
"chamber" : "C01", "C02", etc.
"T_treatment": the long term temperature treatment: "ambient" or "elevated"
"Pot_No" : the pot number. Note that there were multiple pots per chamber early in the experiment.
"Stem": the stem number. Often NA, but has a value for trees that forked.
"Date": the date, in YYYY-MM-DD
"Stem_length_cm" : the length of the stem (cm). Approximately the same as "height".
"first_order_Brs": the number of 1st order branches
"Lvs_whole_tree": the number of leaves counted for the entire tree. Note this was only done twice, for very small trees. Another complete leaf count was done for larger trees later in the experiment: these data are not in this file.
"Diam_15cm" , etc. The rest of the variables are diameter measurements (mm). The variable name refers to the height of the measurement, in cm. 

File prepared by John Drake

@graph.creator: John Drake (je.drake@uws.edu.au)
@graph.description:
Turgor loss point for trees in the fourth whole-tree chamber experiment (WTC4) with Eucalyptus parramattensis, measured prior to the heatwave on Nov 4th, 2016. Turgor loss point was measured via pressure-volume curves by the hydraulics team (Chris Blackman, Rosana Lopez, and Sebastian Pfautsch).

variables:
chamber: the chamber identifier ("C01", "C02", etc).
T_treatment: the long term temperature treatment: ("ambient" or "elevated")
HW_treatment: the heatwave treatment designation ("control" or "heatwave"). Note that the measurements occurred before the heatwave treatment was actually implemented.
subreplicate: either the first or second subreplicate measurement (1 or 2).
TLP: the water potential at which the leaf lost turgor (MPa).

File prepared by John Drake

@graph.creator: Craig Barton (c.barton@uws.edu.au)
@graph.description:
Analysis of wood and bark density from disc segments (i.e., "cookies") taken during the destructive harvest at the end of the fourth whole-tree chamber experiment with Eucalyptus parramattensis. Note that water content can also be calculated from these data. On the second day of the harvest (24 Nov 2016), trees were felled and three discs were taken. Discs were taken from the base (layer = low), from the intersection between the lower and middle canopy thirds (mid), and from the intersection of the middle and upper canopy thirds (layer = top). A disc of ~50-mm-width was cut with a handsaw. The bark and wood were separated by hand, weighed, measured for volume using Archimedes' principle of water displacement on a balance, dried, and weighed again.

Data collection by Craig Barton. File prepared by John Drake.

chamber : the whole-tree chamber ID ("C01", "C02", etc)
layer : the vertical location of the disc ("low", "mid", or "top")
thickness : the average thickness of the disc, measured in 4 places.
diam_over_bark : the diameter of the disc, measured over the bark (mm)
diam_under_bark: the diameter of the disc, measured under the bark (mm)
FM_bark : the fresh mass of the bark (g)
FM_wood : the fresh mass of the wood (g)
fresh_vol_wood : the fresh volume of the wood (cm3)
fresh_vol_bark : the fresh volume of the bark (cm3)
DM_bark : the dry mass of the bark (g)
DM_wood : the dry mass of the wood (g)
density_wood : the density of the wood (DM_wood / fresh_vol_wood; g cm-3)
density_bark : the density of the bark (DM_bark / fresh_vol_bark; g cm-3)

@graph.creator: John Drake (je.drake@uws.edu.au)
@graph.description:
Pressure volume curves (i.e., PV curves) for leaves collected from the fourth whole-tree chamber experiment (WTC4) with Eucalyptus parramattensis. 
Note that these leaves were collected prior to the heatwave. PV curves were measured using the standard bench drying technique (Tyree and Hammel, 1972, Journal of Experimental Botany). Two leaves per tree were sampled on 19 October 2016. 

The data were collected by Chris Blackman, Rosana Lopez, and Sebastian Pfautsch. File prepared by John Drake. 

T_treatment: the long-term experimental warming treatment ("ambient" or "elevated") 
HW_treatment: the heatwave treatment ("control" or "heatwave") 
chamber: the whole-tree chamber identifier ("C01", "C02", etc) 
replicate: the sub-replicate leaf number 
SWC : saturated water content (g) 
Po : osmotic potential at full turgor (MPa) 
YTLP : the water potential at turgor loss point (MPa) 
RWCTLP: relative water content at turgor loss point (%) 
e : modulus of elasticity (MPa) 
CFT : capacitance at full turgor (MPa) 
CTLP : capacitance after (beyond) the turgor loss point (MPa) 
CFT_star : absolute capacitance at full turgor, per unit leaf area (mol m-2 MPa-1)

@graph.creator: Burhan Amiji (b.amiji@uws.edu.au)
@graph.description:
Analysis of stem wood mass taken during the destructive harvest at the end of the fourth whole-tree chamber experiment with Eucalyptus parramattensis. Note that stem water content can also be calculated from these data (average of ~60%). 

On the second day of the harvest (24 Nov 2016), trees were felled in three canopy layers (lower third, middle third, and upper third). The fresh mass of each layer was measured and included in this file. Then, ~six 50-mm-width discs were cut with a handsaw. Discs were taken from the base, from the intersection between the lower and middle canopy thirds, from the intersection of the middle and upper canopy thirds, and from the location of the heat ratio and heat pulse sapflow sensors. These discs are not summarized here, but their biomass was accounted for by weighing the fresh mass of the remaining stem material again (not included in this file). The stem segments were then cut into ~0.5m sections, dried for >2 weeks, and then weighed. The total stem dry weight was calculated as the final dry weight measurement, plus the dry weight of the discs that were removed, assuming that the discs had equivalent moisture content as the dried stem segments.

Data collection by Burhan Amiji and a large team. File prepared by John Drake. 

chamber : the whole-tree chamber ID ("C01", "C02", etc) 
layer : the layer height ("low", "mid", or "top") , refering to the lower third, the middle third, or the upper third
StemFM: the fresh mass of all of the stem wood in that layer (g)
StemDM: the dry mass of all of the stem wood in that layer (g)

@graph.creator: John Drake (je.drake@uws.edu.au)
@graph.description:
Porometer based estimates of stomatal conductance during the fourth heat wave day during the fourth whole-tree chamber experiment with Eucalyptus parramattensis (WTC4). 

During the hot afternoon period of the fourth heatwave day (3 Nov 2016), John Drake and Angelica Varhammar used a Decagon Devices porometer to measure stomatal conductance on the abaxial (lower) leaf surface of three leaves per chamber. All leaves were in the bottom third of the canopy and accessable from the ground. It was extremely hot in the heatwave chambers at this time (air T of ~43 deg C, compared to control chambers of ~28 deg C). Measurements began at 1pm and finished at ~2pm. 

File prepared by John Drake. 

chamber : the whole-tree chamber ID ("C01", "C02", etc) 
T_treatment : the long term temperature treatment ("ambient" or "elevated"). Note that this treatment was not in effect at this time
HW_treatment: the heatwave treatment ("control" or "heatwave")
gs : stomatal conductance as estimated by the porometer (mmol m-2 s-1). Note that these measurements seem to be "too high". Use with caution.

@graph.creator: John Drake (je.drake@uws.edu.au)
@graph.description:
Complete leaf counts for trees in the fourth whole-tree chamber experiment with Eucalyptus parramattensis (WTC4). A team of investigators manually counted all of the leaves on each tree on 7 April 2016. These data are meant to help calculate total canopy leaf area for WTC4.

File prepared by John Drake

chamber : the whole-tree chamber ID ("C01", "C02", etc) 

Date: the date of the counting. 2016-04-07. YYYY-MM-DD

branch : the branch number. Note that branches were numbered from the base to the top. A few branches at the base of each tree were removed to facilitate installing the plastic floor.

leaf_no : the number of leaves on the branch (#). Note that tiny leaves < 5 cm long were excluded from this count.

@graph.creator: John Drake (je.drake@uws.edu.au)
@graph.description:
Measurements of individual leaf size for leaves on trees in the fourth whole-tree chamber experiment with Eucalyptus parramattensis (WTC4). A team of investigators manually measured the area of individual leaves on a subset of branches for each tree on 7 April 2016. These data are meant to help calculate total canopy leaf area for WTC4. Five branches were identified in a stratified random way, from the base to the top of the canopy. Five random leaves on these branches were measured for leaf area using a handheld leaf area meter (licor).

File prepared by John Drake 

chamber : the whole-tree chamber ID ("C01", "C02", etc) 

Stem : the stem number. In most cases this is "1". When the stem forked, each fork was numbered.

branch : the branch number. Note that branches were numbered from the base to the top.

leaf_area : the area of the leaf (cm2)

@graph.creator: John Drake (je.drake@uws.edu.au)
@graph.description:
Measurements of leaf size for leaves on trees in the fourth whole-tree chamber experiment with Eucalyptus parramattensis (WTC4). Groups of leaves were detached and incubated for isotopic analyses associated with the 13C-CO2 pulse chase study. The total leaf area of these incubated leaves was measured with a benchtop leaf area meter (licor), providing an estimate of average leaf size.

File prepared by John Drake 

chamber : the whole-tree chamber ID ("C01", "C02", etc). Note that not all chambers are represented here.
Date : The date of collection, in YYYY-MM-DD
batchtime : the hour (24-hour clock) when the incubation was started
total_area : the total area (cm2) of the leaves
nleaves : the number of leaves in the incubation. (either 6 or 2).
leaf_area : the average leaf size (cm2), calculated as total_area/nleaves

@graph.creator: John Drake (je.drake@uws.edu.au)
@graph.description:
Complete leaf counts for two trees in the fourth whole-tree chamber experiment with Eucalyptus parramattensis (WTC4). Adam Tjoelker manually counted all the leaves on two trees on 26 Aug 2016. These data are meant to help calculate total canopy leaf area for WTC4.

File prepared by John Drake 

chamber : the whole-tree chamber ID (either "C08" or "C09") 


branch : the branch number. Note that branches were numbered from the base to the top. A few branches at the base of each tree were removed to facilitate installing the plastic floor. 

leaf_no : the number of leaves on the branch (#). Note that tiny leaves < 5 cm long were excluded from this count. 
comments: any comments from Adam

@graph.creator: John Drake (je.drake@uws.edu.au)
@graph.description:
Incomplete leaf counts for trees in the fourth whole-tree chamber experiment with Eucalyptus parramattensis (WTC4). A team of investigators manually counted leaves on a subset of branches for each tree on 25 Aug 2016. These data are meant to help calculate total canopy leaf area for WTC4, in the case via a branch allometry.

File prepared by John Drake 

chamber : the whole-tree chamber ID ("C01", "C02", etc) 

Stem : the stem number. In most cases this is "1". When the stem forked, each fork was numbered.

branch : the branch number. Note that branches were numbered from the base to the top. A few branches at the base of each tree were removed to facilitate installing the plastic floor. 

leaf_no : the number of leaves on the branch (#). Note that tiny leaves < 5 cm long were excluded from this count. 

Analyst : the initials of the person that did the counting.

@graph.creator: John Drake (je.drake@uws.edu.au)
@graph.description:
This file contains canopy-scale respiration measurements near the end of the third whole-tree chamber experiment with Eucalyptus tereticornis. These data reflect closed-chamber measurements of whole-canopy respiration, after all of the branches and stems had been removed. As such, these measurements reflect respiration from the standing tree stems. Each chamber was manually transformed into a closed system and the rate of CO2 accumulation within the chamber airspace was used as a measure of whole canopy respiration. The whole-tree chamber environmental controls were used to maintain the air temperature in all chambers at 15 degrees C. 

The respiration rates in this file are calculated from the underlying minutely [CO2] data and were corrected for leaks. See Drake et al. (2016) New Phytologist for details. 

Variables: 
chamber: the chamber number ("C01", "C02", etc).
T_treatment: "ambient" or "elevated" 
StemDM: the dry mass of the stem measured at the harvest (g)
R_stem_nmol: whole-stem respiration rate (nmol CO2 g-1 s-1). Note that this is a tissue-specific flux rate, obtained by dividing the raw flux rate by StemDM.

@graph.creator: John Drake (je.drake@uws.edu.au)
@graph.description:
Aggregation of rainfall data from EucFACE, for use in the soil CO2 efflux project.

The tipping bucket measurements of rainfall from the FACE office lawn and the tops of rings 1, 4, and 3 were combined at 15-minute resolution in this file.

Variables:
DateTime: Date and time variable, in YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS
Rain1: tipping bucket rainfall from the top of ring 1 (mm)
Rain4 tipping bucket rainfall from the top of ring 4 (mm)
Rain3: tipping bucket rainfall from the top of ring 3 (mm)
RainL: tipping bucket rainfall from the office lawn (mm)
Rain: average of Rain1, Rain4, Rain3, and RainL (mm)

@graph.creator: John Drake (je.drake@uws.edu.au)
@graph.description:
Branch hydraulic conductivity of Eucalyptus parramattensis trees in the fourth whole tree chamber experiment (WTC4). These measurements were done by Rosana Lopez along with Chris Blackman and Sebastian Pfaustch during the heatwave portion of the experiment.
One shoot per tree was harvested in the early morning before and just after the heatwave to assess native embolism (i.e., the loss of hydraulic conductivity). One hour before collection, shoots were covered with black plastic bags and sprayed with water to stop transpiration and allow water potential to equilibrate. Shoots were harvested under water and transported to the laboratory with their cut ends immersed in water and their leaves covered to release tension. Two 5 cm long segments were excised under water from terminal parts of each shoot and connected to a flow meter (Bronkhorst High-Tech B.V., Ruurlo, the Netherlands). Hydraulic conductance was measured at low pressure (≤ 2 kPa) before (kini) and after (kfin) flushing with ultrapure, degassed 2 mmol KCl solution at high pressure for 30 min. Percentage loss of hydraulic conductivity (PLC) was calculated as: PLC = 100 - kini / kfin * 100. Actual hydraulic conductance values based on ki and kf were calculated using the measured pressure gradient, sample length, and xylem area. The values of kini and kfin are the raw values of the flowmeter and have units of %; these should not be used for comparison between samples- they are only valid to calculate the plc because the pressure gradient in each sample was maintained at a common value.

Variables:
chamber: "C01", "C02", etc
T_treatment: the long term temperature treatment- ("ambient" or "elevated")
HW_treatment: the heatwave treatment ("control" vs. "heatwave")
Date: the date in YYYY-MM-DD
branch: the subreplicate number (1 or 2)
kini: the initial flow measurement (%; raw off instrument)
kfin: the final flow measurement (%; raw off instrument)
plc: the percentage loss of hydraulic conductivity in native state relative to rehydrated state (%)
Ksi: the hydraulic conductivity in the native state (Kg m-1 s-1 MPa-1)
KSf: the hydraulic conductivity in the rehydrated state (Kg m-1 s-1 MPa-1)

File prepared by John Drake

@graph.creator: John Drake (je.drake@uws.edu.au)
@graph.description:
Leaf hydraulic conductivity for Eucalyptus parramattensis trees in the fourth whole tree chamber experiment (WTC4). These data were collected by Chris Blackman et al. during the heatwave.
Leaf hydraulic conductivity (Kleaf) was measured using the kinetics of leaf water potential relaxation upon leaf rehydration. One 30-40 cm branch per tree before, during and after the heatwave were collected early in the morning and transported to the laboratory in black plastic bags. Branches were cut to a length sufficient to prevent emboli from extending into the petioles of the leaves. Once in the lab, branches were allowed to desiccate slowly for up to 48 hrs, before being carefully bagged to prevent water loss and equilibrate water potential throughout the branch. Initial ΨL was determined by measuring one leaf neighbouring the sample leaves in a pressure chamber. Two sample leaves were then cut under water and allowed to rehydrate for 15-20 s and final leaf water potential was measured with the pressure chamber. Kleaf was calculated as Kleaf = Cleaf ln[Ψo/Ψf]/t where Ψo = initial leaf water potential (MPa); Ψf = final leaf water potential (MPa); t = duration of rehydration (s); Cleaf = leaf capacitance (mmol m-2 MPa-1).

The method is further described by:
Brodribb TJ & Holbrook NM. Stomatal closure during leaf dehydration, correlation with other leaf physiological traits. Plant Physiology 132, 2166-2173 (2003).
Variables:
T_treatment: the long term temperature treatment ("ambient" or "elevated")
HW_treatment: the heatwave treatment ("control" or "heatwave")
chamber: the chamber ID ("C01", "C02", etc)
subreplicate: the subreplicate number (1 or 2)
LWP_init: the initial leaf water potential, measured on an adjacent leaf (MPa)
Kleaf: leaf hydraulic conductance (mmol m-2 s-1 MPa-1).

File prepared by John Drake

@graph.creator: John Drake (je.drake@uws.edu.au)
@graph.description:
Daily estimates of total crown leaf area and mass for trees in the fourth whole-tree chamber experiment with Eucalyptus parramattensis (WTC4). 

These values were estimated via the approach outlined in Drake et al. (2016) New Phytologist and Barton et al. (2012) Global Change Biology. Total whole-crown leaf area was estimated three times during the experiment. (1) There was a complete leaf count performed on 2016-04-07, along with measurements of average leaf size. Total leaf area was calculated as the product of leaf number and leaf size. (2) There was an incomplete leaf count performed again on 2016-08-25, where all leaves on a subset of branches was counted. Adam Tjoelker also counted all leaves on C08 and C09 on 2016-08-26. We developed a branch allometry to predict branch-scale leaf area from branch length and relative insertion point. This branch allometry was used to predict the total leaf area of each tree crown; these estimates were off by ~10% relative to Adam’s compete count. (3) Total crown leaf area was estimated at the final harvest as total leaf mass multiplied by specific leaf area for each crown third.

These three estimates of total crown leaf area were combined with litterfall estimates to create a relationship between log10(height) and log10(cumulative leaf area production). Trees had different intercepts, but equivalent slopes. This relationship was used to calculate the cumulative leaf area produced on each date when tree height was measured directly, from which standing leaf area was calculated by subtracting the cumulative sum of litterfall measured prior to the date in question. These estimates were then linearly interpolated through time to produce these estimates of total leaf area at a daily scale. Leaf mass was calculated from leaf area using the average SLA values obtained at the final harvest.

File prepared by John Drake 

chamber : the whole-tree chamber ID ("C01", "C02", etc). 
Date : The date, in YYYY-MM-DD 
leaf_area : the total area (m2) of all leaves in each tree crown
SLA: the specific leaf area measured at the final harvest, averaged across canopy layers (cm2 g-1)
leaf_mass: the total mass (g) of all leaves in each tree crown

@graph.creator: John Drake (je.drake@uws.edu.au)
@graph.description:
Canopy harvest data from the fourth whole-tree chamber experiment (WTC4) with Eucalyptus parramattensis. On the first day of the harvest (23 Nov 2016), branches were removed from each tree by cutting flush to the stem insertion point and aggregated into three canopy layers (lower third, middle third, and upper third). For each aggregate branch sample (e.g., the lower third canopy layer of C02), all leaves were manually removed and composited. Petioles stayed with the leaves, not the branches. 

Leaves. The aggregate pile of leaves for each canopy layer was mixed by hand, and a random subsample of 100 leaves was selected (most frequently exactly 100, occasionally 99 or 101). The total leaf area of this subsample was measured with a licor rotary leaf area meter, and the subsample was further measured for fresh mass and dry mass. Specific leaf area (SLA) was calculated from these measurements. The leaves remaining (i.e., the leaves not in the 100-leaf subsample) were also measured for fresh and dry mass. Total leaf dry mass for the layer was calculated as the sum of the dry masses for the bulk leaf sample and the 100-leaf subsample. Total leaf area for the layer was calculated as total leaf dry mass multiplied by SLA and divided by 10000 to covert to square meters of leaf area.

Branches. All branches of each canopy layer were composited after leaf removal. John Drake removed a single branch per sample for the lower and middle third of each canopy for measurements of branch respiration rate. This branch was dried and weighed separately. The remaining pile of branches was measured for fresh and dry mass. Total branch dry mass was calculated as the sum of the respiration branch dry mass and the bulk branch sample dry mass.

Variables:
chamber : the whole-tree chamber ID ("C01", "C02", etc) 
layer : the layer height ("low", "mid", or "top") , refering to the lower third, the middle third, or the upper third 
total_leaf_DM : the total dry mass of leaves in that canopy layer (g). Sum of sample_leaf_DM and subsample_leaf_DM
total_leaf_area : the total area of leaves in that canopy layer (m2). Product of total_leaf_DM and SLA, divided by 10000 to convert cm2 to m2.
total_branch_DM : the total dry mass of branches in that canopy layer (g). Sum of sample_branch_DM and respiration_branch_DM.
sample_leaf_FM : the fresh mass of leaves in the main sample (g)
sample_leaf_DM : the dry mass of leaves in the main sample (g)
sample_branch_FM : the fresh mass of branches in the main sample (g)
sample_branch_DM : the dry mass of branches in the main sample (g)
respiration_branch_DM : the dry mass of the branch used for respiration measurements (g). Note that such a sample was not taken for the upper canopy third.
leaf_no_in_subsample : the number of leaves included in the “100-leaf” subsample
subsample_leaf_FM : the fresh mass of leaves in the 100-leaf subsample (g)
subsample_leaf_area : the total area of the leaves in the 100-leaf subsample (cm2)
subsample_leaf_DM : the dry mass of leaves in the 100-leaf subsample (g)
SLA : the specific leaf area calculated as the ratio of subsample_leaf_area and subsample_leaf_DM (cm2 g-1)

@graph.creator: John Drake (je.drake@uws.edu.au)
@graph.description:
Coarse root harvest data from the fourth whole-tree chamber experiment (WTC4) with Eucalyptus parramattensis. The entire soil volume was excavated for each tree between 28 Nov to 13 Dec 2016. Chambers were excavated from the soil surface down to the hardlayer of cemented manganese. The depth of this manganese layer varied across chambers from a minimum of 62.8 cm to 105.8 cm. Excavation was done by hand using mattocks and shovels. Soil was shoveled out of the chambers onto a moving treadmill that transported the soil onto a coarse sieve, where roots were picked by an operator. Note that this was a lot of manual work, as several tons of soil had to be moved by hand. Thus on most days, only a single chamber was excavated per day.

Roots were subsequently separated into diameter size classes (0-2mm, 2-10mm, >10mm, and the root bole), washed, dried, and weighed. Note that we did not trust the data for the 0-2mm size class- we think we missed a large fraction of these small roots. Thus, use the fine root data from the soil coring to estimate fine root mass for this experiment (WTC_TEMP-PARRA_CM_BIOMASS-ROOT-CORES_20161125-20161128_L1.csv).


Variables:
chamber : the whole-tree chamber ID ("C01", "C02", etc) 
CR_DM_2to10 : the total coarse root dry mass of roots from 2-10mm in diameter (g)
CR_DM_10plus: the total coarse root dry mass of roots greater than 10mm in diameter, excluding the root bole (g)
CR_DM_bole: the total coarse root dry mass of the root bole (g)
CR_DM_total: the total coarse root dry mass (g). The sum of CR_DM_2to10, CR_DM_10plus, and CR_DM_bole
